Hugh Willoughby, 15th Baron Willoughby of Parham, was born in 1713 and became the 15th Baron after his father's death in 1715. He was placed under the guardianship of his mother and Reverend John Walker, but his mother remarried in 1717, forfeiting her joint guardianship. Hugh Willoughby attended Rivington Grammar School and later transferred to a Non-conformist school in Taunton, where he met a lifelong friend. In 1732, he received the freedom of Dumfries. In 1840, Charles Wheatstone introduced a device called the chronoscope, which was used to measure minute intervals of time. This device was capable of distinguishing 1/7300 part of a second and was used to determine the speed of a bullet or the passage of a star. Wheatstone also exhibited an electro-magnetic clock at the Royal Society on 26 November 1840, which was capable of distributing the correct time to local timepieces. Alexander Bain, who worked as a mechanist for Wheatstone from August to December 1840, later accused Wheatstone of stealing his ideas for an electric clock and an electro-magnetic printing telegraph. However, Wheatstone maintained that he had experimented in that direction during May. In the same year, Bain mentioned his financial problems to the editor of the Mechanics Magazine, who introduced him to Wheatstone. Bain demonstrated his models to Wheatstone, who dismissed them as having no future. Three months later, Wheatstone demonstrated an electric clock to the Royal Society, claiming it was his own invention. What was the primary purpose of the chronoscope introduced by Charles Wheatstone in 1840?

Raymond Bernard's career spanned over three decades, with significant shifts in his film-making style and scale. He began as an actor in his father's plays, then transitioned to directing, and later focused on historical spectacles. During World War II, his film-making was interrupted due to his Jewish identity. After the war, he returned to directing, but his later films were more modest in scale. In the 1970s, he supervised the reconstruction of his earlier film adaptation of Victor Hugo's "Les Misérables". Hedwig of Mecklenburg-Güstrow was a member of the House of Mecklenburg and by marriage became the Duchess of Saxe-Merseburg-Zörbig. She was the eighth child of Gustav Adolph, Duke of Mecklenburg-Güstrow and Magdalene Sibylle of Holstein-Gottorp.
